Lyndon Johnson received 48.9 percent of the southern white popular vote in 1964 to this candidate's 49 percent, a remarkable achievement given that his administration had been defined by its fight to overturn segregation.

Robert Chambliss was the ringleader of the four Klansmen who bombed a Birmingham church in 1963, killing four black schoolgirls. J. Edgar Hoover had assigned 231 FBI agents to the investigation and Chambliss was under 24-hour surveillance. But the investigation was sabotaged by Colonel Al Lingo, the Alabama public safety director, who arrested Chambliss on a lesser charge of illegal possession of explosives so the FBI would find it impossible to build enough evidence to mount a prosecution. Chambliss pleaded guilty to the charge and served six months in jail. Not until 1977 was he found guilty of the church bombing.
